validation_metadata.verified_by: Claude Code AI Assistant  - Manual Extraction
validation_metadata.verification_method: Complete manual review of Idaho Code Title 74, Chapter 1, Sections 74-101 through 74-126

rights_of_access.description: Every person has a right to examine and take a copy of any public record of this state. There is a presumption that all public records in Idaho are open at all reasonable times for inspection except as otherwise expressly provided by statute.
rights_of_access.conditions: Subject to statutory exemptions; available at reasonable times; applies to all public records
rights_of_access.applies_to: Any person - no residency requirement for right itself, though response times vary
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Broad definition of 'person' includes individuals, corporations, partnerships, etc. Strong presumption toward openness.
rights_of_access.request_tips: Assert: 'Under Idaho Code § 74-101, I have the right to examine and copy [specific records]. Please provide access pursuant to Idaho's statutory presumption of openness.'

rights_of_access.description: Idaho law does not require requesters to state their purpose for requesting public records. No restrictions on how records may be used after disclosure.
rights_of_access.conditions: No purpose justification needed; no use restrictions imposed
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Removes common barrier - requesters need not explain or justify their interest in records
rights_of_access.request_tips: If asked for purpose: 'Idaho Code does not require me to state my purpose for this request. Please process without purpose justification.'

rights_of_access.description: For Idaho residents, agencies must grant or deny request for examination or copying within 3 working days of receiving the request.
rights_of_access.conditions: Applies to Idaho residents only; 3 working days to grant or deny; longer times permitted with notice if records need more than 3 days to produce
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Quick turnaround for residents; 'grant or deny' means agency must make decision within 3 days even if production takes longer
rights_of_access.request_tips: Idaho residents: 'As an Idaho resident, Idaho Code § 74-103 requires you to grant or deny my request within 3 working days. Please provide prompt response.'

rights_of_access.description: If longer time is needed to produce records, agency must notify requester in writing and provide records within 10 working days.
rights_of_access.conditions: Applies when records cannot be produced within 3 days; requires written notice of delay; maximum 10 working days for production after notice
rights_of_access.applies_to: Idaho residents when records require additional processing time
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Two-step process: 3 days to decide + up to 7 more days to produce (10 days total from request)
rights_of_access.request_tips: If delayed beyond 3 days: 'Idaho Code § 74-103 permits extension but requires written notice and production within 10 working days total. Please provide written notification and confirm 10-day deadline.'

rights_of_access.description: Agencies may waive fees if the request contributes significantly to public understanding of government operations or activities. This promotes transparency and accountability.
rights_of_access.conditions: Must contribute significantly to public understanding; fee waiver is discretionary; applies to requests serving public interest
rights_of_access.applies_to: Requests that serve public understanding of government
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Similar to federal FOIA public interest fee waiver; supports journalism, research, and citizen oversight
rights_of_access.request_tips: Request waiver: 'I request fee waiver under Idaho Code § 74-102 as this request contributes significantly to public understanding of [government operation/activity]. [Explain public benefit].'

rights_of_access.description: Fees charged for public records cannot exceed actual labor and copying costs. Agencies cannot profit from providing public records.
rights_of_access.conditions: Fees limited to actual costs only; cannot include overhead, administrative markup, or profit
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Actual cost standard prevents excessive fees being used as barrier to access
rights_of_access.request_tips: Challenge excessive fees: 'Idaho Code § 74-102 limits fees to actual labor and copying costs. Please provide itemized breakdown showing actual costs, not estimated or inflated amounts.'

rights_of_access.description: Labor costs must be calculated based on the rate of pay for the lowest-paid staff member capable of performing the task. This minimizes labor charges.
rights_of_access.conditions: Staff time calculated at lowest capable employee rate; prevents agencies from charging high-level staff rates for simple tasks
rights_of_access.applies_to: All labor charges for public records production
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: If clerk can do task, agency cannot charge manager's rate; ensures labor fees are minimal
rights_of_access.request_tips: Question labor charges: 'Idaho Code § 74-102 requires labor costs be based on lowest-paid capable staff member. Who performed this work and what is their hourly rate?'

rights_of_access.description: When a record contains both exempt and non-exempt material, the custodian shall separate the exempt and non-exempt material and make the non-exempt material available for examination.
rights_of_access.conditions: Applies when records are partially exempt; requires physical separation; non-exempt portions must be disclosed
rights_of_access.applies_to: All requests where records contain mixed exempt/non-exempt content
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Agencies cannot withhold entire document because one portion is exempt; must redact and release public portions
rights_of_access.request_tips: Demand segregable portions: 'Idaho Code § 74-112 requires you to separate and disclose non-exempt portions. Please provide redacted records showing what is being withheld and why.'

rights_of_access.description: In district court proceedings, the burden of proof is on the agency to justify withholding of public records. Requester does not have burden to prove entitlement.
rights_of_access.conditions: Applies in all judicial enforcement actions; agency must prove exemption applies; court determines matter de novo
rights_of_access.applies_to: All litigation over denied public records requests
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Burden-shifting provision - you don't prove you should get records; agency must prove they can withhold
rights_of_access.request_tips: In court: 'Idaho Code § 74-115 places burden on your agency to justify this withholding. I need not prove my entitlement to these public records.'

rights_of_access.description: Court may examine records in camera (privately in judge's chambers) to determine whether exemption applies. Provides neutral evaluation of agency claims.
rights_of_access.conditions: Available in judicial proceedings; judge reviews disputed records privately; determines if exemption justified
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Prevents agencies from hiding behind blanket exemption claims - judge can verify whether records are actually exempt
rights_of_access.request_tips: Request in camera review: 'If this matter proceeds to court, Idaho Code § 74-115 authorizes the judge to review these records in camera to verify your exemption claim.'

rights_of_access.description: Court may award reasonable attorney fees and costs to requester if the request was not frivolously pursued, even if requester does not fully prevail. This encourages legitimate enforcement.
rights_of_access.conditions: Request must not be frivolous; fees discretionary with court; available even for partial success
rights_of_access.applies_to: Requesters who pursue judicial enforcement in good faith
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Lower bar than 'substantially prevail' standard - protects requesters who pursue legitimate claims even if not fully successful
rights_of_access.request_tips: Note fee-shifting: 'Idaho Code § 74-117 provides for attorney fees if my request is not frivolously pursued. I am prepared to litigate if necessary.'

rights_of_access.description: Any person denied access to public records may file proceedings in district court of the county where records are located to compel disclosure.
rights_of_access.conditions: File in district court of county where records located; no administrative appeal required; direct judicial review available
rights_of_access.applies_to: All denied public records requests in Idaho
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Idaho does not require exhaustion of administrative remedies - requesters can go directly to court after denial
rights_of_access.request_tips: After denial: 'Idaho Code § 74-115 authorizes me to file district court proceedings to compel disclosure. Please reconsider or I will pursue judicial enforcement.'

rights_of_access.description: Public officials who deliberately refuse to allow inspection or copying in violation of the Public Records Act are subject to penalties up to $1,000.
rights_of_access.conditions: Refusal must be deliberate and improper; penalty up to $1,000; creates personal accountability for officials
rights_of_access.applies_to: Public officials who improperly deny access
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Personal liability provision - officials face financial penalty for deliberate violations; strengthens compliance incentive
rights_of_access.request_tips: Warn of penalty: 'Idaho Code § 74-116 imposes penalties up to $1,000 on officials who deliberately refuse access improperly. Please ensure your denial is legally justified.'

rights_of_access.description: Court may order immediate disclosure of wrongfully withheld records. Provides expedited relief when agency denial is improper.
rights_of_access.conditions: Available upon court finding that records were wrongfully withheld; court has authority to order prompt production
rights_of_access.applies_to: Improperly denied records in judicial proceedings
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Courts can compel immediate disclosure rather than allowing prolonged withholding during litigation
rights_of_access.request_tips: In court: 'Request immediate disclosure order under Idaho Code § 74-115 if court finds records were improperly withheld.'

rights_of_access.description: Individuals have the right to examine their own personal records maintained by agencies. Separate provision ensures access to information about oneself.
rights_of_access.conditions: Applies to records about the requesting individual; supports privacy rights and data accuracy
rights_of_access.applies_to: Individuals seeking their own personal records
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Personal records may have different disclosure rules than general public records; individuals have special access to information about themselves
rights_of_access.request_tips: Request personal records: 'Under Idaho Code § 74-103, I request access to my personal records maintained by your agency.'

rights_of_access.description: Writing includes all electronic data compilations from which information may be obtained or translated. Electronic records have same status as paper records.
rights_of_access.conditions: Electronic records treated same as physical records; includes databases, magnetic media, diskettes, sound recordings, etc.
rights_of_access.applies_to: All electronic government records and data compilations
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Broad electronic records definition ensures modern formats covered; agencies cannot deny access based on electronic format
rights_of_access.request_tips: For electronic records: 'Idaho Code § 74-101 defines public records to include electronic data compilations. Please provide access to [database/electronic records] in native electronic format.'

rights_of_access.description: Non-residents may receive responses within up to 35 days following request. While longer than resident timeline, non-residents still have access rights.
rights_of_access.conditions: Applies to non-Idaho residents; up to 35 days response time; ensures non-residents can still access Idaho public records
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Idaho differentiates timelines by residency but does not exclude non-residents entirely; 35 days is maximum, not requirement
rights_of_access.request_tips: Non-residents: 'As a non-resident, Idaho Code § 74-103 provides for response within 35 days. Please confirm expected response date.'
